para.emphasis: This article applies to Shorewall 3.0 and later. If you are running a version of Shorewall earlier than Shorewall 3.0.0 then please see the documentation for that release.

article.para: OpenVPN is a robust and highly configurable VPN (Virtual Private Network) daemon which can be used to securely link two or more private networks using an encrypted tunnel over the internet. OpenVPN is an Open Source project and is licensed under the GPL. OpenVPN can be downloaded from http://openvpn.net/.
OpenVPN support was added to Shorewall in version 1.3.14.

warning.para: The default port number for OpenVPN changed from 5000 to 1194 in Shorewall version 2.2.0 RC2. This change follows OpenVPN 2.0 which also changed its default port to 1194. In the text that follows, where you see Port 1194 this can also refer to port 5000 depending on which version of Shorewall and OpenVPN that you are using.

section.title: Preliminary Reading
section.para: I recommend reading the VPN Basics article if you plan to implement any type of VPN.

section.title: Bridging two Masqueraded Networks
section.para: Suppose that we have the following situation:

We want systems in the 192.168.1.0/24 subnetwork to be able to communicate with the systems in the 10.0.0.0/8 network. This is accomplished through use of the /etc/shorewall/tunnels file and the /etc/shorewall/policy file and OpenVPN.
While it was possible to use the Shorewall start and stop script to start and stop OpenVPN, I decided to use the init script of OpenVPN to start and stop it.
On each firewall, you will need to declare a zone to represent the remote subnet. We'll assume that this zone is called vpn and declare it in /etc/shorewall/zones on both systems as follows.

blockquote.programlisting: #ZONE TYPE OPTIONS IN OUT # OPTIONS OPTIONS vpn plain

section.para: On system A, the 10.0.0.0/8 will comprise the vpn zone.

blockquote.programlisting: #ZONE INTERFACE BROADCAST OPTIONS vpn tun0

section.para: In /etc/shorewall/tunnels on system A, we need the following:

blockquote.programlisting: #TYPE ZONE GATEWAY GATEWAY ZONE openvpn net 134.28.54.2

note.para: Shorewall versions prior to 2.2.0 Beta 1 enforced use of the same port number for both the source and destination port.

Some OpenVPN clients (notabley on Windows) do not use the same source and destination ports which can cause problems. If system B is a Windows system or if you find that Shorewall is blocking the UDP port 1194 traffic from the remote gateway and you are running a version of Shorewall prior to 2.2.0 Beta 1, then you will want the following entry in /etc/shorewall/tunnels instead of the one above:
note.programlisting: #TYPE ZONE GATEWAY GATEWAY ZONE generic:udp:1194 net 134.28.54.2

section.para: This entry in /etc/shorewall/tunnels opens the firewall so that OpenVPN traffic on the default port 1194/udp will be accepted to/from the remote gateway. If you change the port used by OpenVPN to 7777, you can define /etc/shorewall/tunnels like this:

blockquote.programlisting: #TYPE ZONE GATEWAY GATEWAY ZONE openvpn:7777 net 134.28.54.2

section.para: This is the OpenVPN config on system A:

blockquote.programlisting: dev tun local 206.162.148.9 remote 134.28.54.2 ifconfig 192.168.99.1 192.168.99.2 up ./route-a.up tls-server dh dh1024.pem ca ca.crt cert my-a.crt key my-a.key comp-lzo verb 5

section.para: Similarly, On system B the 192.168.1.0/24 subnet will comprise the vpn zone

blockquote.programlisting: #ZONE INTERFACE BROADCAST OPTIONS vpn tun0 192.168.1.255

section.para: In /etc/shorewall/tunnels on system B, we have:

blockquote.programlisting: #TYPE ZONE GATEWAY GATEWAY ZONE openvpn net 206.191.148.9

section.para: And in the OpenVPN config on system B:

blockquote.programlisting: dev tun local 134.28.54.2 remote 206.162.148.9 ifconfig 192.168.99.2 192.168.99.1 up ./route-b.up tls-client ca ca.crt cert my-b.crt key my-b.key comp-lzo verb 5

section.para: You will need to allow traffic between the vpn zone and the loc zone on both systems -- if you simply want to admit all traffic in both directions, you can use the policy file:

blockquote.programlisting: #SOURCE DEST POLICY LOG LEVEL loc vpn ACCEPT vpn loc ACCEPT

section.para: On both systems, restart Shorewall and start OpenVPN. The systems in the two masqueraded subnetworks can now talk to each other.

section.title: Roadwarrior
section.para: OpenVPN 2.0 provides excellent support for roadwarriors. Consider the setup in the following diagram:
On the gateway system (System A), we need a zone to represent the remote clients — we'll call that zone road.

blockquote.programlisting: #ZONE TYPE OPTIONS IN OUT # OPTIONS OPTIONS road plain

section.para: On system A, the remote clients will comprise the road zone.

blockquote.programlisting: #ZONE INTERFACE BROADCAST OPTIONS road tun+

section.para: In /etc/shorewall/tunnels on system A, we need the following:

blockquote.programlisting: #TYPE ZONE GATEWAY GATEWAY ZONE openvpn:1194 net 0.0.0.0/0

section.para: If you are running Shorewall 2.4.3 or later, you might prefer the following in /etc/shorewall/tunnels on system A. Specifying the tunnel type as openvpnserver has the advantage that the VPN connection will still work if the client is behind a gateway/firewall that uses NAT.

blockquote.programlisting: #TYPE ZONE GATEWAY GATEWAY ZONE openvpnserver:1194 net 0.0.0.0/0

section.para: We want the remote systems to have access to the local LAN — we do that with an entry in /etc/shorewall/policy (assume that the local LAN comprises the zone loc).

blockquote.programlisting: #SOURCE DESTINATION POLICY road loc ACCEPT

section.para: The OpenVPN configuration file on system A is something like the following:

blockquote.programlisting:
dev tun
server 192.168.2.0 255.255.255.0
dh dh1024.pem
ca /etc/certs/cacert.pem
crl-verify /etc/certs/crl.pem
cert /etc/certs/SystemA.pem key /etc/certs/SystemA_key.pem
port 1194
comp-lzo
user nobody
group nogroup
ping 15 ping-restart 45 ping-timer-rem persist-tun persist-key
verb 3

section.para: Configuration on the remote clients follows a similar line. We define a zone to represent the remote LAN:

blockquote.programlisting: #ZONE TYPE OPTIONS IN OUT # OPTIONS OPTIONS home plain

section.para: On system A, the hosts accessible through the tunnel will comprise the home zone.

blockquote.programlisting: #ZONE INTERFACE BROADCAST OPTIONS home tun0

section.para: In /etc/shorewall/tunnels on system B, we need the following:

blockquote.programlisting: #TYPE ZONE GATEWAY GATEWAY ZONE openvpn:1194 net 206.162.148.9

section.para: Again in you are running Shorewall 2.4.3 or later, in /etc/shorewall/tunnels on system B you might prefer:

blockquote.programlisting: #TYPE ZONE GATEWAY GATEWAY ZONE openvpnclient:1194 net 206.162.148.9

section.para: We want the remote clien to have access to the local LAN — we do that with an entry in /etc/shorewall/policy.

blockquote.programlisting: #SOURCE DESTINATION POLICY $FW home ACCEPT

section.para: The OpenVPN configuration on the remote clients is along the following line:

blockquote.programlisting:
dev tun remote 206.162.148.9 up /etc/openvpn/home.up
tls-client pull
ca /etc/certs/cacert.pem
cert /etc/certs/SystemB.pem key /etc/certs/SystemB_key.pem
port 1194
user nobody group nogroup
comp-lzo
ping 15 ping-restart 45 ping-timer-rem persist-tun persist-key
verb 3

section.para: If you want multiple remote clients to be able to communicate openly with each other then you must:

listitem.para: Include the client-to-client directive in the server's OpenVPN configuration; and
Specify the routeback option on the tun+ device in /etc/shorewall/interfaces.

section.para: If you want to selectively allow communication between the clients, then see this article by Marc Zonzon
